INTERCOLLEGIATE NEWS
An entirely novel and unique
method has been introduced at
New York University in the rehearsal of plays. It provides, essentially, for the installation of microphones on the stage where the
play is being rehearsed, which will
record every word spoken by the
actors and actresses. The record
will first be impressed on wax and
then a permanent phonograph record will be made.
It is said that two great advantages are possessed by this system. First, it will afford the players an opportunity to hear their
own voices and make their own
corrections. The coach will not
speak a word while the rehearsal
is going on, but will wait for .he
permanent records to be placed on
a phonograph. A still greater advantage, it is said, is the fact that
after the performance of the play
has been entirely perfected, permanent records may be made and
filed for future reference.

Student actors will soon be able
to hear, by this method, interpretations which have made great
roles famous on the stage. Walter

THE POOR PROFESSORS
The American public has a stock impression of the college
professor which it dislikes to change. In the popular conception all professors are absent-minded, near-sighted, gentle, and
afflicted with liver complaint. They all wear outlandishly oldfashioned clothes, spectacles, and umbrellas. They are all seventy-five years of age or older.
A recent article in Collier's gives an example of what the
much-mentioned "man in the street" likes to believe of collegiate educators. The coeds of a Southern college had failed an
intelligence test. The story goes that the test was then given
to the faculty, who made an even more miserable showing.
Moral, according to Collier's: All college professors are lacking
in common sense.
The examples quoted as being instances of the faculty's
worst and most ludicrous blunders were: Al Jolson was said
to be a wrestling champion; the purposes of Brilliantine were
confused; filet mignon was called the name of an opera by Puccini; and Grover Cleveland Bergdoll was said to be a -World
War hero.
Whether familiarity with comedians and patent beautifiers
is a mark of intelligence might be contested. And of the other
two "imbecile" blunders it is just possible that the confusion of
food with music was done intentionally by someone who found
Puccini vapid—for if there isn't an Italian opera called "Filet
Mignon" there should be. And plain healthy facetiousness
rather than failure to keep in touch with the world's progress
seems the answer to the last example of professorial feeblemindedness.
Those who still cherish with the illusion that all policemen
are big-footed Irishmen the belief that all professors have
chronic stigmatism and disordered livers, might do well to observe the Hopkins faculty, or certain members of it. Not only
is there an instructor who is a baseball player but there is a
certain group among the faculty who romp about at dusk on the
upper quadrangle like playground children. A man with weak
eyes and a dilapidated liver might conceivably play tennis or
golf but free-for-all soccer is a different matter. The American
public is invited to watch some seven or eight university professors or near professors clad in "unmentionables" chasing a
soccer ball with the vim of a high school boy.

The News-Letter regrets to announce the resignation
of Arthur L. Nelson, '26, from the position of Associate Editor.

All letters intended for publication
must be concise, written in ink on
regular letter size paper, on one side

evidence of good faith will not be

interest.

March 28, 1925.
To the Editor, THE NEWS-LETTER.
Dear Sir: To judge from the
talk of certain members of the
Freshman class, it seems that all the
men with brains in the University
Engineering School of the Junior
and Senior classes are members of
Tau Beta Pi. It is to correct this
impression that this article is written. The requirements for membership in Tau Beta Pi, according
to the Y. M. C. A. Handbook, are
that a man must be of high scholastic standing and must also be engaged , in some activity on the
campus. All well and good, if these
requirements are followed, but they

STAR OF "TAILOR-MADE MAN" WILL
GO ON STAGE AFTER GRADUATION
I. Evans (Bill) Rodgers, star of
"A Tailor-Made Man," expects to
pursue a stage career upon receiving his degree from Johns Hopkins. So said he last Monday in
an interview with a reporter from
the News-Letter.
At present Rodgers is in the
School of Engineering, but he anticipates changing to the College
of Arts and Sciences next fall.
"Engineering," he said, "is about
the most unpleasant thing in my
life. Next year, I expect to study
English, and subjects that will fit
me for the stage."
Though very few people seem
to be aware of the fact, this was
Rodgers' first performance in a
speaking role. Hitherto, all his
acting has been in musical comedy
work—either singing, dancing, or
both. Previous to this year, he
has had no opportunity to play
dramatic roles.
Most of his work has been with
the "Poly Follies," with which he
was connected for four years. Join-

ing the -Follies" in his sophomore
year, he immediately made the
cast. For the two following seasons, he was one of the mainstays
of the show. The next year he did
not take part in the performance
but assisted his cousin with the
coaching. Two years ago, he was
offered a position on the Keith
Circuit to act with Alva Weaver,
formerly of Baltimore City College, in a combination singing and
dancing stunt. His mother objected, however, so he remained at
school. Since then, though, he
has made up his mind to turn his
histrionic ability into his life
work.
Rodgers considers his part in
"A Tailor-Made Man" his real opportunity. "The Barnstormers
Club has been a great joy to me,"
he remarked. "It has given me
some real experience in dramatics."
During the summer, "Bill" will
coach dramatics at a boys' camp in
the Adirondacks.

INTERCOLLEGIATE NEWS
An entirely novel and unique
method has been introduced at
New York University in the rehearsal of plays. It provides, essentially, for the installation of microphones on the stage where the
play is being rehearsed, which will
record every word spoken by the
actors and actresses. The record
will first be impressed on wax and
then a permanent phonograph record will be made.
It is said that two great advantages are possessed by this system. First, it will afford the players an opportunity to hear their
own voices and make their own
corrections. The coach will not
speak a word while the rehearsal
is going on, but will wait for .he
permanent records to be placed on
a phonograph. A still greater advantage, it is said, is the fact that
after the performance of the play
has been entirely perfected, permanent records may be made and
filed for future reference.

Student actors will soon be able
to hear, by this method, interpretations which have made great
roles famous on the stage. Walter

THE POOR PROFESSORS
The American public has a stock impression of the college
professor which it dislikes to change. In the popular conception all professors are absent-minded, near-sighted, gentle, and
afflicted with liver complaint. They all wear outlandishly oldfashioned clothes, spectacles, and umbrellas. They are all seventy-five years of age or older.
A recent article in Collier's gives an example of what the
much-mentioned "man in the street" likes to believe of collegiate educators. The coeds of a Southern college had failed an
intelligence test. The story goes that the test was then given
to the faculty, who made an even more miserable showing.
Moral, according to Collier's: All college professors are lacking
in common sense.
The examples quoted as being instances of the faculty's
worst and most ludicrous blunders were: Al Jolson was said
to be a wrestling champion; the purposes of Brilliantine were
confused; filet mignon was called the name of an opera by Puccini; and Grover Cleveland Bergdoll was said to be a -World
War hero.
Whether familiarity with comedians and patent beautifiers
is a mark of intelligence might be contested. And of the other
two "imbecile" blunders it is just possible that the confusion of
food with music was done intentionally by someone who found
Puccini vapid—for if there isn't an Italian opera called "Filet
Mignon" there should be. And plain healthy facetiousness
rather than failure to keep in touch with the world's progress
seems the answer to the last example of professorial feeblemindedness.
Those who still cherish with the illusion that all policemen
are big-footed Irishmen the belief that all professors have
chronic stigmatism and disordered livers, might do well to observe the Hopkins faculty, or certain members of it. Not only
is there an instructor who is a baseball player but there is a
certain group among the faculty who romp about at dusk on the
upper quadrangle like playground children. A man with weak
eyes and a dilapidated liver might conceivably play tennis or
golf but free-for-all soccer is a different matter. The American
public is invited to watch some seven or eight university professors or near professors clad in "unmentionables" chasing a
soccer ball with the vim of a high school boy.

The News-Letter regrets to announce the resignation
of Arthur L. Nelson, '26, from the position of Associate Editor.

March 28, 1925.
To the Editor, THE NEWS-LETTER.
Dear Sir: To judge from the
talk of certain members of the
Freshman class, it seems that all the
men with brains in the University
Engineering School of the Junior
and Senior classes are members of
Tau Beta Pi. It is to correct this
impression that this article is written. The requirements for membership in Tau Beta Pi, according
to the Y. M. C. A. Handbook, are
that a man must be of high scholastic standing and must also be engaged , in some activity on the
campus. All well and good, if these
requirements are followed, but they

STAR OF "TAILOR-MADE MAN" WILL
GO ON STAGE AFTER GRADUATION
I. Evans (Bill) Rodgers, star of
"A Tailor-Made Man," expects to
pursue a stage career upon receiving his degree from Johns Hopkins. So said he last Monday in
an interview with a reporter from
the News-Letter.
At present Rodgers is in the
School of Engineering, but he anticipates changing to the College
of Arts and Sciences next fall.
"Engineering," he said, "is about
the most unpleasant thing in my
life. Next year, I expect to study
English, and subjects that will fit
me for the stage."
Though very few people seem
to be aware of the fact, this was
Rodgers' first performance in a
speaking role. Hitherto, all his
acting has been in musical comedy
work—either singing, dancing, or
both. Previous to this year, he
has had no opportunity to play
dramatic roles.
Most of his work has been with
the "Poly Follies," with which he
was connected for four years. Join-

ing the -Follies" in his sophomore
year, he immediately made the
cast. For the two following seasons, he was one of the mainstays
of the show. The next year he did
not take part in the performance
but assisted his cousin with the
coaching. Two years ago, he was
offered a position on the Keith
Circuit to act with Alva Weaver,
formerly of Baltimore City College, in a combination singing and
dancing stunt. His mother objected, however, so he remained at
school. Since then, though, he
has made up his mind to turn his
histrionic ability into his life
work.
Rodgers considers his part in
"A Tailor-Made Man" his real opportunity. "The Barnstormers
Club has been a great joy to me,"
he remarked. "It has given me
some real experience in dramatics."
During the summer, "Bill" will
coach dramatics at a boys' camp in
the Adirondacks.
